author: yblue19
content: Looking at the current polygon clog due to a single game traffic, I wonder if the community is thinking about how to deal with congestion control with an alternative fee structure. Even if the fee is super low, and the TPS is 10k/s, it's entirely possible that there are bots to submit enough transactions to clog the network or jack up the fees.

author: yblue19
content: In the "web0" world like TCP there are classic algorithm on congestion control at per flow level to ensure fairness.

author: pietjepuk
content:
I'm not sure how you would use TCP/IPs congestion control for space on the blockchain. Could you elaborate?

Also, check this out if you haven't already: https://polynya.medium.com/transaction-quality-trilemma-4af36704590b

author: yblue19
content: I'm not sure either. :p Just random ideas pop up in my head. The polynya article is a great read. IIUC, the direction we are heading to is a high fee L1, plus a low fee but with enough censorship L2?

author: pietjepuk
content:
Time will tell, but roughly speaking I'm inclined to agree that's the direction we're heading. There are some ways around the censorship resistance as well, but how costly those are remains to be seen. The incentives are certainly such that block producers on both L1 and L2 become centralized if they aren't from the start. I'm still hoping for a "magic"  / moon math fix that allows them to stay decentralized ðŸ˜‰

Another related read for you if you haven't seen it yet: https://vitalik.ca/general/2021/12/06/endgame.html
